content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I was kidding earlier lol. Nice clash!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Not very difficult but could be fun in the fastest mode

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like the review of Kepler's 3rd law, and I believe the practice of converting physics/math word equations into code is useful for anyone studying game programming.

While the coding part of this is very easy, I enjoyed this clash because it gave a quick review of Kepler's third law.  I personally don't think the subject is too complicated, as the bold text transcribes to the equation you need.  It is more of a math word problem more than a coding problem, but I would claim that being able to interpret and understand basic math and physics formulas is an important skill to acquire for game programming.

As this is intended as clash of code, the text and the subject are too complicated. 
Even after studying 10min at wikipedia and other sources, I could not really figure out the formula T=sqrt(R^3/k). Please keep in mind that users of CG are usaully not native speakers. So I believe this is too dificult for a clash of code puzle.
You could try it as a classical puzzle, or you make a much easier and have the formula given in the text.
After hearing your feedback I've simplified the input and output.
I do agree with the other comment, text is too long and redundant. If it wasn't for this I would have approved :)
I'd recommend making the output not require a full sentence but just the time in days, the planet name also seems redundant to me. Besides that it's a pretty nice puzzle!

I disagree. I'm not a native speaker either, but knowing how to interpret physical laws is crucial in university and much more if one's adventuring in the field of computer science.

Even ignoring Kepler's Third Law, you can reverse engineer the equation using pen and paper and the units of the constant:
(distance)³ = AU³/day² * (days)²
(days)² = (distance)³ / (AU³/day²)
days = sqrt( (distance)³ / (AU³/day²) )
T = sqrt(R³ / k)

I think it's an important skill to be able to interpret mathematical laws with pen & paper, especially since Computer Science is full of them!
